questions.text: Which pattern of microcalcification seen in a patient’s mammography report would indicate the maximum risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Cluster microcalcification in mammography indicates the maximum risk of malignancy.

Breast cancer, the most common cancer globally, accounts for 2.3 million new cases annually, with 70% of deaths occurring in resource-constrained areas due to late detection. WHO’s Global Breast Cancer Initiative (GBCI) aims to reduce mortality by 2.5% annually by 2040 through early detection, timely diagnosis, and comprehensive care. This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, under the theme 'No one should face breast cancer alone' highlights the need for early detection, patient support, and stronger partnerships to address disparities and improve outcomes.

Related Pearl: Types of microcalcification indicating malignancy

In decreasing order of risk of malignancy-

  • Cluster microcalcification (maximum risk)
  • Linear microcalcification
  • Segmental microcalcification
  • Diffuse microcalcification (minimum risk)

questions.text: Amongst the following, the most common cause of blood-stained nipple discharge from a single duct is:
questions.solution:
Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of blood-stained nipple discharge from a single duct.

Solitary intraductal papillomas are true polyps of the ducts which are usually small (<1 cm) but may grow to 4-5 cm. They are often associated with bloody nipple discharge. They do not have malignant potential. Treatment is by excision.

Note: The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lump in the left breast as shown in the image below. Biopsy done revealed increased stromal cellularity with typical leaflike architecture. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Treatment is wide excision with margin
Originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology report point to malignant cystosarcoma phyllodes, which metastasize via the bloodstream. Metastasis to lymph nodes is rare.

Phyllodes tumor also known as a sero-cystic disease of Brodie or cystosarcoma phyllodes, originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. It is usually a benign condition and affects women >40 years of age, but can be seen in younger women. Sometimes, may develop malignant transformation.

Clinical features:

  1. Large, sometimes massive, with an unevenly bosselated surface
  2. Ulceration of overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis
  3. Remains mobile on the chest wall

There is no role of FNAC in phyllodes tumor. Histopathology of the lump biopsy shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture.

Tumors are treated by excision with margins of at least 2 cm to prevent local recurrence.

Large or malignant phyllodes tumors may require a mastectomy. The axillary dissection is not recommended because axillary lymph nodes rarely get involved.

Note: Malignant phyllodes tumors contain liposarcomatous or rhabdomyosarcomatous elements rather than fibrosarcomatous elements.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breast lumps?

Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).

LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients with LCIS. 

Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of the primary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancer within the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it).

questions.text: What is not true regarding a Bochdalek hernia?

choices.text: Early respiratory distress leading to early diagnosis and treatment is a good prognostic sign
The contents of hernial sac commonly includes retroperitoneal fat, left kidney or spleen
The condition is diagnosed prenatally by ultrasonography.
Pericardial cyst is a differential diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Early respiratory distress, within 6 hours of birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.

Features of a Bochdalek hernia:

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Ultrasonography findings:

  • Polyhydramnios
  • Chest mass
  • Mediastinal shift
  • Gastric bubble or a liver in the thoracic cavity
  • Fetal hydrops

Differential diagnosis:

  • Eventration
  • Cystic lung lesion (pulmonary sequestration or cystic adenomatoid Malformation)
  • Group B streptococcal sepsis: associated with delayed onset of symptoms and a CDH often on the right side.
  • Pneumothorax: always occurs on contralateral to the side of CDH.

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair

The viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fio2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with long-standing complaints of dysphagia which was getting worse for the past 4 months. A barium swallow was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is the definitive treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical management is the first-line treatment modality. 

Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction. 

Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s beak’.

Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the procedure of choice. Here, the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia are cut. However, this can cause iatrogenic gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) due to damage to the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Thus, newer techniques involve a partial fundoplication like Dor's procedure to reinforce the sphincter and reduce GERD symptoms. 

Endoscopic myotomy is a newer, alternate procedure. Here, a submucosal tunnel is formed in the mid esophagus region that allows a long myotomy. 

Option A: Calcium channel blockers can be given in the initial stages of the disease. They relieve the chest pressure that occurs around mealtimes. However, they are not permanent treatments and can be used while waiting for surgery.  

Option B: Botulinum toxin injection can be used as a treatment in patients who may not be candidates for surgery or dilatation. Limitations to botulinum toxin injections are that the effect is short-lived (6-12 months) and patients often require multiple treatments.

Option C: Pneumatic dilatation of the LES has is successful in 75% of patients. It involves using a balloon to stretch the LES and improve competence. It requires multiple sessions and has a low risk of esophageal perforation.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of nonprogressive dysphagia for solids with no previous similar episodes. Barium swallow revealed fixed narrowing of the esophagus at the level of the aortic arch. CT angiography revealed the following. Which anomaly is most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the origin of the aberrant right subclavian artery (red arrow) causing extrinsic compression of the esophagus that is suggestive of dysphagia lusoria.

In dysphagia lusoria, the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch instead of branching from the brachiocephalic artery. It then courses behind the esophagus to supply blood to the right arm. This causes pressure on the esophagus and results in dysphagia. 

It is diagnosed by CT angiography. A barium swallow shows fixed narrowing of the esophagus at the level of the aortic arch without mucosal abnormality.

Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is true about the condition?

choices.text: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier's disease.

Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.

There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema.

Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below.

Cetuximab, an EGFR inhibitory antibody, is now considered the first-line treatment for Menetrier's disease, leaving total gastrectomy for severe disease with persistent and substantial protein loss refractory to cetuximab.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure shown below.
questions.solution:
The procedure illustrated in the image is Billroth II gastrectomy. Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to the jejunum.

Option A: In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

Option C: Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy is Billroth II reconstruction with jejunojejunostomy.

Option D: Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy is a gastric bypass surgery where a loop of jejunum is anastomosed to a proximal gastric pouch.

questions.text: During an appendectomy, the mesoappendix is divided and ligated. Which of the following is false about the major vessel ligated in this step?

choices.text: It is a branch of upper division of the ileocolic artery
Thrombosis is most common at the tip

questions.solution:
During appendectomy, the appendicular artery is the major vessel that is ligated when the mesoappendix is divided. It is a branch of the lower division of the ileocolic artery.

The appendicular artery transverses behind the terminal ileum and enters the mesoappendix away from the base of the appendix. It lies along the free border of the mesoappendix. The terminal part or the tip of the artery lies on the wall of the appendix and may become thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis.

It supplies only the appendix and is an end-artery.

An accessory appendicular artery called the artery of Seshachalam may be present. It anastomoses at the base of the appendix with a branch of the posterior cecal artery.

questions.text: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.

Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

questions.text: Which fascial layer should be dissected to separate the rectum from the coccyx while operating on a patient with rectal adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Waldeyer's fascia separates the rectum from the coccyx. 

The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following:

  • from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia
  • from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer’s fascia

Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into superior and inferior compartments. 

Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.

  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: While performing the HIDA scan in a patient with gallstones, the gallbladder was not visualized. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Non-visualization of the gallbladder in HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scan is suggestive of acute cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis is the inflammation of the gallbladder that develops over hours, usually because a gallstone obstructs the cystic duct. In the majority of cases, the process is limited by the stone slipping back into the body of the gallbladder. Clinical features include:

  • Pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back
  • Fever
  • Nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia
  • Jaundice
  • Positive Murphy's sign
  • Positive Boas' sign

Murphy's sign: After asking the patient to exhale, the examiner places his hand below the costal margin on the right side at the mid-clavicular line of the patient. The patient is then instructed to take a deep inspiration. If the patient stops breathing and winces with a ‘catch’ of breath, Murphy’s sign is said to be positive.

Boas' sign: It is the presence of an area of hyperaesthesia at the site of radiation of the pain to the back, typically, below the scapula.

USG and CT scans are helpful in establishing a diagnosis. The gold standard investigation of acute cholecystitis is the HIDA scan. The radioisotope used is Technetium-99m ( 99mTc)-labeled derivative of iminodiacetic acid.

The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder is not visualized even after 4 hours.

 

Unlike bilirubin, iminodiacetic acid (IDA) compounds do not undergo conjugation in the hepatocytes. They are rapidly excreted into the bile. This enables excellent visualization of the bile ducts and gallbladder within 30–60 minutes of injection.

Since cystic duct obstruction initiates acute cholecystitis, there is non-visualization of the gallbladder 3 - 4 hours after the intravenous injection of 99m Tc-IDA. This is characteristic of acute cholecystitis. Thus visualization of the GB establishes cystic duct patency and rules out acute cholecystitis.

    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)

    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. CT scan of the abdomen revealed the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows the Mercedes-Benz sign. It is a characteristic sign seen in gallstones.

In gallstone, rarely, the center of the stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on a radiograph called the Mercedes–Benz sign (triradiate sign) or seagull sign (biradiate sign).

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient was admitted with right hypochondriac pain and vomiting. USG demonstrates a stone within the bile duct. All of the following clinical features can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The presence of a stone within the bile duct is called choledocholithiasis. Murphy's sign is not seen in choledocholithiasis. It is seen in acute cholecystitis.

Clinical features of choledocholithiasis:

  • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, which may radiate to the back
  • Biliary colic
  • Vomiting
  • Dyspepsia
  • Flatulence
  • Food intolerance particularly to fatty foods
  • Altered bowel habits
  • Jaundice.

Other Murphy's in surgery:

Murphy's punch sign: This test is performed by the examiner using the fist to make jabbing thrusts over the costovertebral angle. The test is positive in infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney.

The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column. 

Murphy's triad is associated with acute appendicitis.

  • Pain in the right illiac fossa
  • Vomiting
  • Fever

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding focal nodular hyperplasia?

choices.text: Resection is done for persistent symptomatic cases
Appears as hotspots in Tc 99m sulphur colloid scan

questions.solution:
Malignant transformation is unlikely in focal nodular hyperplasia.

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for FNH. It is seen as a well-circumscribed lesion with a typical central scar. They show intense homogeneous enhancement on the arterial phase and isodense as compared to the background liver on the venous phase.

Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as hotspots on Tc 99m sulphur colloid scans.

Asymptomatic patients with typical radiologic features do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases.

Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old retiree was employed for two decades in a plastic industry, where he was exposed to vinyl chloride. He is at an increased risk of developing which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Angiosarcoma of the liver is seen in workers who have been exposed to vinyl chloride for prolonged periods.

Angiosarcoma is the most common malignant mesenchymal tumor of the liver. It is a rare and fatal tumor.

They are associated with the following conditions:

  • Hemochromatosis
  • Neurofibromatosis type I
  • Exposure to vinyl chloride, thorium dioxide, and arsenic.

Patients usually present with vague symptoms of abdominal pain, weakness, fatigue, and weight loss. A hepatic bruit is occasionally heard, reflecting the vascular nature of the tumor.

Central hypovascularity, vascular lakes, and peripheral contrast staining on arteriography are suggestive of an angiosarcoma. Biopsy shows the presence of dilated sinusoids lined by atypical endothelial cells.

questions.text:
A lady underwent a left hemicolectomy for colon cancer 5 days back. She now complains of abdominal discomfort and bloating. She is still unable to pass gas. On examination, the abdomen is distended and no bowel sounds are heard. X-ray shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following will be part of the management plan of the patient?
  1. Initiation of oral intake
  2. Nasogastric tube decompression
  3. Electrolyte correction
  4. CT-scan
  5. Emergency laparotomy
questions.solution:
The given post-op scenario after 72 hours of laparotomy with no passage of flatus, absent bowel sounds, and X-ray findings are suggestive of paralytic ileus. Initiation of oral intake and emergency laparotomy is not done in paralytic ileus.

The return of normal motility post-surgery occurs in the following sequence:

Small intestine (within the first 24 hours) → Stomach (within 48 hours) → Colon (3 to 5 days).

Paralytic ileus is an adynamic/functional obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. This is secondary to neuromuscular failure in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) and submucous (Meissner’s) plexuses. Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain.

The resultant stasis leads to the following clinical features:

  • Abdominal distension - marked and tympanitic
  • Effortless vomiting 
  • Absence of bowel sounds
  • Absolute constipation

Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy after handling of the bowel:

  • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
  • No passage of flatus

Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple air fluid levels in an erect X-ray. A CT scan is more accurate for differentiating functional from mechanical obstruction

Paralytic ileus is managed by nasogastric tube decompression and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text: A young male, who wishes to pursue his higher studies abroad gets a chest X-ray done as a part of the immigration clearance. X-ray shows air under bilateral domes of the diaphragm. He is currently asymptomatic with normal vital signs.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an asymptomatic patient having air under the diaphragm without evidence of peritonitis (sterile pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of pneumatosis intestinalis.

Pneumatosis intestinalis presents as multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract. It is usually located in the subserosa, submucosa, and rarely the muscularis layer.

The common sites are jejunum > ileocecal region > colon. It represents one of the few cases of sterile pneumoperitoneum.

Pneumatosis in neonates is usually associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.

Predisposing factors include:

  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Immunocompromised state 
  • Inflammatory, obstructive, or infectious conditions of the intestine
  • Endoscopy and jejunostomy
  • Ischemia
  • Diabetes

Patients can be asymptomatic. Symptoms if present, is usually nonspecific like:

  • Diarrhoea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Abdominal distention
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Weight loss
  • Mucus in stool

Diagnosis can be made on the basis of:

  • Plain X-ray showing radiolucent areas within the bowel wall (appear as grape-like clusters or tiny bubbles)
  • Barium contrast
  • CT studies

Treatment involves:

  • Management of the uncomplicated primary disease.
  • When symptoms demand treatment, the first line is intermittent high flow oxygen therapy, providing a concentration of 70% continuously for 5 days by nasal specula.
  • The cysts may also resolve with antibiotics, particularly metronidazole.
  • In resistant cases, maintenance treatment with sulfasalazine may be helpful. The prognosis in most patients is that of the underlying disease.

questions.text: A surgeon sees a necrotic bowel when operating on a child for an inguinal hernia. What is true about the resection and anastomosis of the bowel?

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures
The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique
The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique

questions.solution:
The standard technique used currently for resection anastomosis of the bowel is a one-layer extra mucosal suture technique since it causes the least tissue necrosis and luminal narrowing. Interrupted and continuous single-layer suture techniques are adequate and safe.

The extra mucosal suture must also include the submucosa because this layer has a high collagen content and it is the most stable suture layer in all sections of the gastrointestinal tract.

Catgut has now been replaced with absorbable synthetic polymers. Stapling devices can be used when speed is required.

questions.text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.

  1. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. 
  2. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.

Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

questions.text: A jeep driver presented with a swelling in the natal cleft, with pain, difficulty in sitting, and occasional purulent discharge from the area. Examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Hair follicles are seen in the wall of sinus
Hirsute habitus is a risk factor
Commonly seen between the ages of 15 and 40 years

questions.solution:
The given condition is a pilonidal sinus. Hair follicles have almost never been demonstrated in the walls of the sinus. The hair projecting from the sinus is dead hair, with its pointed ends directed towards the blind end of the sinus.

Pilonidal sinus disease is a disease of the inter-gluteal region, characterized by the formation of a sinus in the cleft of the buttocks. It is more common in males between 15-40 years of age.

Risk factors include:

  1. Male sex
  2. Family history
  3. Being overweight or obese
  4. Trauma or irritation to the perianal region
  5. Occupations involving sitting for long periods- jeep/lorry drivers
  6. Hirsute habitus - thick body hair
  7. Poor hygiene

Sites involved:

  1. Natal cleft (most commonly)
  2. Interdigital cleft
  3. Face
  4. Axilla

Buttock friction and shearing forces in these areas allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can arise as openings, lined with granulation tissue and discharge.

Clinical features:

  • Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine
  • Abscess - due to a foreign-body-type reaction 

Treatment

  • Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area.
  • Abscess:
    • Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair.
  • Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease.

Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

questions.text: A 68- year-old patient presents with difficulty in initiating micturition. A DRE reveals an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml and a biopsy result was suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition ?

choices.text: PSA is a not specific marker for the condition.
Gleason score correlates with the pathological stage
It is associated with decreased % free PSA
It arises from the transitional zone of the gland.

questions.solution:
Prostatic carcinoma, as indicated in the clinical scenario, arises from the peripheral zone of the gland.

Anatomically, the prostate is divided into three zones. 

  • The peripheral zone lies posteriorly and has an abundance of prostatic glands. 
  • The central zone lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the seminal vesicles as they course through the prostate. 
  • The transitional zone is periurethral.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia arises from the transitional zone.

Gleason grading may be used after biopsy to evaluate the stage of histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is high risk.

PSA (prostatic specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH.

Slightly elevated total PSA (between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL) and low free PSA (<25%) is suspicious for prostate cancer.

questions.text: Identify the pathological finding indicated by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Structures represented by the one marked by the arrow are identified as corpora amylacea.

They are tiny calcified lamellated bodies found in the glandular alveoli of elderly men. 

It is hypothesized that they are the fore-runners of prostatic caliculi.

questions.text: A newborn was diagnosed with undescended testes. Due to the intra-abdominal location of the testes, a two-stage Stephen-Fowler’s orchiopexy was planned. Which of the following is performed during the first stage of this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the first stage of a two-stage Stephens-Fowler approach, the testicular vessels are clipped. 

Clipping of the testicular artery promotes neo vasculogenesis along the vas deferens. It does not result in ischemia of the testis due to the presence of collaterals from the cremasteric artery and the artery to the ductus deferens (deferential artery).

Several months later, after collaterals are established, the second stage is performed during which the testis and its new blood supply is mobilized into the scrotum.

Stephen-Fowler’s approach is done when an intra abdominal testes is located too far to reach the scrotum. Alternatively, Silbar’s orchiopexy may be done. In this procedure, microvascular anastomosis of the testicular vessels with internal illiac vessels is done after the testis is mobilised to the scrotum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma.

The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance.

Other options:

Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance. Histologically, they are typically composed of a lace-like (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, which generally show less cytologic atypia than embryonal carcinoma. In approximately 50% of tumors, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies) may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli. 

Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.  Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds. More undifferentiated lesions may display sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and have hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli. The cell borders are usually indistinct, and there is considerable variation in cell and nuclear size and shape (pleomorphism). Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells are frequently seen.

Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types. Histologically, collections of differentiated cells or organoid structures originating in all 3 germ layers can be seen. Elements may be mature (resembling various adult tissues) or immature (sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue).

questions.text: What is the appropriate age at which corrective surgery should be done for the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows penoscrotal hypospadias. Operations for hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months.

Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons. The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

  • Orthoplasty - Chordee correction
  • Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening
  • Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans
  • Skin cover and scrotoplasty

Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

 Complications of hypospadias surgery include:

  • Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)
  • Recurrence of chordee
  • Urethral stricture
  • Meatal stenosis
  • Infection

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in patients with penile cancer?
questions.solution:
Inguinal lymph node status is the most important prognostic indicator in penile carcinoma.

The prognosis for tumors confined to the penis is good with 5-year survival rates in excess of 80%. With nodal involvement, the 5-year survival rate falls to around 40%.

questions.text: An elderly man on follow-up for treatment of bladder cancer presents with painless hematuria. Which of the following assays should be done on this patient?
questions.solution:
An NMP 22 assay should be done in this patient to detect the recurrence of bladder carcinoma. 

NMP 22 is a nuclear matrix protein that is used to form cell nuclei. It is shed into the urine and has a higher concentration in the urine of bladder cancer patients. NMP-22 cutoff levels for bladder cancer detection is > 10 units/mL.

questions.text: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection undergoes voiding cystourethrogram. It shows reflux of urine into the pelvis and calyces, without dilation of the ureter. What is the grade of vesicoureteric reflux?
questions.solution:
Reflux of urine into pelvis and calyces without dilatation is Grade II vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).

VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common clinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE DESCRIPTION
I Reflux into a non-dilated ureter
II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation of the ureter
III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyses; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: Which of the following head injury patients need not undergo head CT at this point in time?

choices.text: An RTA victim with GCS score of 12
A patient with an episode of vomiting
A child with an episode of seizure post-trauma
A biker with suspected skull fracture

questions.solution:
A single episode of vomiting after a head injury is not an indication for immediate CT brain. However, more than one episode mandates a scan.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.

It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in males. Usually, no treatment is required.

A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.text: A 42-year-old  daily wage laborer comes to you with discoloration of her legs. She was diagnosed with varicose veins 5 years ago which was left untreated. Identify the feature given in the picture.
questions.solution:
Atrophia blanche is localised white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankles. This is a sign of chronic venous disease.

Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to 'inverted champagne bottle' appearance.

 

Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding complications of varicose vein surgery is false?

choices.text: Injury to the lymphatic system can cause secondary lymphoedema
Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg
The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
The sural nerve accompanies the short saphenous vein laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.

The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the great saphenous vein.

Surgery for the varicose veins extraction may trigger injury of the lymph vessels and may lead to secondary lymphedema.

Injury and inflammation to the venous system during varicose vein surgery can cause slowing and stasis of blood flow in the lower limb, making them prone to develop deep vein thrombosis postoperatively.

questions.text: While fixing faulty wiring, an electrician sustains the given burn. Which of the following is false?

choices.text: Electric burns are usually third degree burns
Urine output should be monitored for volume and deposits
ECG should be monitored even in low voltage burns
Fluid requirement is less as compared to other burns

questions.solution:
Fluid requirement is more as compared to other burns. All electric burns are managed by resuscitation at 4mL/Kg/%TBSA (which means 4mL for every Kg for every %TBSA). This is double what the ATLS guidelines advise for other burns as electrical burns may cause myoglobinuria and acute kidney injury.

Most of the electrical burns are of severe degree and cause third-degree burns.

The fluid resuscitation is done to ensure urine output of 100 mL/hr in adults and 1–1.5 mL/kg/hr in children < 30 kg, until the urine clears from pigmentation. The IV fluid is then titrated down to ensure the urine output of 0.5 mL/Kg/hr.

Electrical injuries are usually divided into low and high-voltage injuries.

  • Low voltage injuries cause small, localized, deep burns.
  • High voltage injuries damage by flash (External burn) and conduction (Internal burn)

The myocardium may be directly damaged without pacing interruption. Thus, ECG must be monitored for arrhythmias.

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man came to the casualty 12 hours after sustaining a laceration on his leg from a trekking accident. On closer examination, other than dirt, you do not notice any pus or signs of infection. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Closure after granulation tissue has formed
Delayed closure 2 days after removal of devitalised tissue
Primary closure after adequate wound toileting and debridement
Wound debridement, topical antibiotics and dressing

questions.solution:
Contaminated wounds older than 6 hours should be managed with delayed primary closure. 

The wound is cleaned, debrided, and left open for a few days. This allows soft tissues to drain and also ensures no infection is present before surgical closure can be done. 

Wound closure is categorized into primary, secondary, or tertiary:

Primary closure is done for clean wounds with minimal tissue loss that are amenable to approximation of wound edges. Healing occurs by primary intention. Primary closure is ideally performed within 6 to 8 hrs of trauma, but wounds in vascular areas (e.g. face) may be delayed to up to 24 hours after trauma. 

Secondary closure allows healing by secondary intention. The wound is left open to heal largely by the formation of granulation tissue and contraction. These wounds often have significant tissue loss precluding tension-free approximation of edges, with devitalized edges. Wound dressings are changed daily to aid in the formation of granulation tissue and subsequent contraction. 

Tertiary closure, also known as delayed primary closure, results in a combination of healing by primary and secondary intention. The wound is thoroughly irrigated, debrided, and left open for 2 to 5 days before surgical closure. It is used for wounds that are grossly contaminated without significant tissue loss.

questions.text: The forearm of a patient admitted to the psychiatric ward is shown in the image. Which of the following is true about the healed injury?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hypertrophic scars which have developed on possible sites of self-inflicted cuts. Type 3 collagen fibers are arranged parallelly in hypertrophic scars. This is in contrast to a keloid where the collagen fibers are more and randomly arranged. 

Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time. They have no racial or genetic predilection.

questions.text: The given image shows a forearm flap harvested for the reconstruction of the oral cavity of a 45-year-old patient with squamous cell carcinoma. Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. Fasciocutaneous radial forearm free flap is the most common free flap used in head and neck reconstruction. 

A flap defines the tongue of tissue whereas a pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

In a free flap, the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site. Other Eg for free flaps: free fibular flap, DIEP flap (Deep inferior epigastric perforators)

Option A: Axial flaps are much longer and are based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus Dorsi flap, TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap.

Option B: An islanded flap is that in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Option D: A random flap includes three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. Eg: V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg, or rhomboid flap.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent a skin-sparing mastectomy a year ago has returned to your clinic to discuss her options for breast reconstruction. All of the following are options to consider except:

choices.text: A TRAM flap provides the best cosmetic result than LD flap
An LD flap provides adequate bulk of breast tissue
Reconstruction may be delayed or immediate
Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants

questions.solution:
An LD flap does not provide the bulk required and is usually used along with an implant. It is based on the thoracodorsal pedicle. It is an axial flap. 

Transverse rectus abdominus myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on superior epigastric or inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM). Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest. It provides good cosmesis and bulk. An implant is usually not required.Since the rectus abdominis muscle is excised in the procedure, it can lead to abdominal wall weakness and hernias.

The timing of reconstruction may be immediate or delayed. Impediments to immediate reconstruction include insufficient theatre time and a lack of experienced reconstructive surgeons. In addition, the patient is likely to need post-op radiotherapy, then a delayed reconstruction using a flap often gives better results.

The easiest type of reconstruction is using a silicone gel implant under the pectoralis major muscle. Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants.

questions.text: During rounds, you have been asked to examine a patient with an ulcer over the face. Which of the following features will raise the suspicion of it being squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
On examination of an ulcer, everted margins will be suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in-situ include:

  • Bowen's disease
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Cautery ablation
  • Cryotherapy
  • Drug therapy including imiquimod
  • Moh’s microsurgery
  • Radiation therapy

questions.text: A 75-year old man came with complaints of a painless nodule on the left palm for the past 4 weeks. He gave a history of sustaining a thorn prick injury to the palm 5 weeks ago. On examination, the lesion appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing an exophytic nodule with central keratinous debris is suggestive of keratoacanthoma.

Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma. It presents clinically as a proliferating dome-shaped keratin-filled crater. Patients usually give a prior history of minor trauma. Treatment of choice is an excisional procedure with 4 mm margins.

Option A: Actinic keratoses consist of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the sun-exposed skin. They arise in middle-aged to older adults and have some potential for malignant transformation.

Option B: Bowen's disease appears histologically as SCC in situ. It initially presents with a red­dened area that progresses to thickened plaques and may vary from small lesions (<1 cm) to large areas. When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen disease is sometimes referred to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T cell lymphoma, and plaque-stage lesions are seen.

A 66-year-old diabetic patient with a frail built comes to the OPD. His wife is concerned about his recent weight loss and lack of appetite. Which parameters will you consider while assessing his malnutrition using MUST?
  1. BMI
  2. Age
  3. Recent weight loss
  4. Current nutritional intake
  5. Acute illness
questions.solution:
Age is not a criterion used in MUST.

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST) is a five-step screening tool to identify malnourished adults or adults at risk of malnutrition.

Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool, ‘MUST’ is a five-step screening tool to identify adults, who are malnourished, at risk of malnutrition (undernutrition), or obese. It also includes management guidelines which can be used to develop a care plan.

questions.text: A patient on total parenteral nutrition may develop a deficiency of _______
questions.solution:
A patient on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may develop a deficiency of zinc, among others.

The commencement of TPN may precipitate or accentuate underlying nutrient deficiency by encouraging anabolism.

Complications of TPN:

  • Infections
    • Highest risk - femoral vein
    • Lowest risk - subclavian vein
  • Metabolic complications
    • CO2 retention and respiratory insufficiency due to excess calorie infusion
    • Hepatic steatosis and marked glycogen deposition
    • Cholestasis and gallstones
  • Intestinal atrophy
    • Mucosal atrophy
    • Bacterial overgrowth
    • Impaired gut immunity

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

questions.text: The type of knot seen in the image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen. This is seen in a reef knot.

A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

Types of knots:

  1. Granny knot: half-hitch over a half-hitch in the same direction. It has better-holding power than half-hitch
  2. Reef knot: half-hitch followed by a second half-hitch after squaring. 
  3. Triple throw knot: Reef knot with another half-hitch knot for added security. Knots made with prolene sutures require 6-8 throws to prevent slippage.
  4. Surgeon’s knot: Modification of the reef knot with two half-hitches in the first layer.
  5. Slip knot: Modification of either granny/reef knot formed when one end of the thread is kept taut while tightening the knot.

questions.text: While assisting on laparoscopic cholecystectomy, you notice the given instruments are used to create a pneumoperitoneum. Select the true statement:

choices.text: Proper placement of the needle can be seen by reaspirating injected saline
It is the most widely used open technique for creating pneumoperitoneum
It involves blind puncture of the peritoneum

questions.solution:
The image is that of a Veress needle and trocar which is involved in blind puncture of the peritoneum.

There are two methods used for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum:

  1. Closed method
  2. Open method

The closed method using the Veress needle has a small but significant potential for intestinal or vascular injury on the introduction of the needle or trocar. Proper placement of the needle can be determined by the inability to re-aspirate injected saline. The normal insufflation rate is 4-6 litres/min.

The use of the open technique for creating a pneumoperitoneum avoids the morbidity related to a blind puncture.

To achieve this, a 1 cm vertical or transverse incision is made at the level of the umbilicus, stay sutures are applied, and the fascia is dissected. Free penetration into the abdominal cavity is confirmed by the gentle introduction of a finger. A Hasson trocar, shown below, is inserted and anchored, and pneumoperitoneum is created. This is the Hasson or modified Hasson approach. 

This method is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound.

questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress soon after birth. On examination, the child has frothing of saliva and the resident suspects tracheoesophageal fistula. What is the most common type of fistula likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution:
Type C is the commonest variety of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). 

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. The proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. 

Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggest a diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Bishop-Koop anastomosis is done for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Bishop-Koop Anastomosis and Mikulicz enterostomy are done for meconium ileus.

Meconium ileus (also known as DIOS - Distal Intestinal Obstructive Syndrome) is defined as intestinal obstruction due to inspissated meconium within the terminal ileum. 

In the Bishop-Koop procedure, the proximal distended limb is joined to the side of the distal small bowel. This is vented by a 'chimney' to the abdominal wall. The Bishop–Koop operation with its irrigating stoma is now only rarely used.

  • Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard operation for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
  • Kasai procedure is done for biliary atresia.
  • Duhamel, Soave, Swenson procedures are done in Hirschsprung’s disease.

questions.text: An infant presents with copious bilious vomiting and abdominal distension on the 5th day of life. He had not passed meconium for the first 3 days after birth. An abdominal radiograph shows the presence of dilated bowel loops. What is the gold standard investigation for the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung’s disease.

A rectal biopsy 2 cm above the dentate line is the ideal area for a biopsy.

Hirschsprung’s disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The initial investigation is a contrast enema. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone. The affected part shows the absence of ganglion cells and hypertrophy of nerve trunks in the rectal biopsy.

Other investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

  • Water-soluble contrast enema - shows the presence of contracted aganglionic rectum, transition zone, and a dilated normally innervated colon.
  • Anorectal manometry - shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure, where endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum. The ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the intensive care unit following a trauma to the abdomen. His intraabdominal pressure is found to be 24 mmHg. What is the grade of abdominal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Intraabdominal pressure (IAP) of 24 mm Hg falls under grade III of intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH).

Normal intraabdominal pressure is 5 to 7 mmHg. Any acute process in the abdomen such as trauma, intestinal perforation, peritonitis, or acute pancreatitis can increase the intra-abdominal pressure. Increased abdominal pressure can diminish the blood flow to the abdominal organs and decrease the venous return to the heart.

Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome.

Grade II 16–20 mmHg

Grade III intra-abdominal hypertension is associated with hypoxia, ARDS and serious complications. It is associated with abdominal compartment syndrome which is defined as a sustained IAP >20 mmHg associated with organ dysfunction/failure.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation

<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A patient with untreated severe peripheral arterial disease comes to the surgery OPD with a right leg as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

It is a surgical emergency if crepitus is felt on palpation
Occurs when tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of blood stream
Amputation is not done if severe sepsis is present

questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from gangrene of the foot. If there is severe sepsis and if re-establishing blood supply is difficult(revascularization) then amputation is the preferred choice of treatment.

Gangrene refers to death of macroscopic portions of tissue which turn black because of the breakdown of haemoglobin and the formation of iron sulphide.

It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus or arteritis).

Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the bloodstream. Wet Gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be palpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms commonly in diabetic foot problems.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncope and cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practice sessions.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded.

Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of the subclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in the vertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia.

Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm of the affected side are found to be feeble.

Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography.

It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.

questions.text: You are tasked with giving post-operative care to a patient who just underwent open abdominal surgery. Which of the following is the most effective treatment to prevent the patient from developing deep vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Heparin, especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is more effective for prophylaxis of DVT in patients who have undergone major surgeries where early ambulation is not possible. 

The choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma, and duration of postoperative immobilisation. Major trauma, abdominal and orthopaedic surgeries warrant a longer duration of postoperative immobilisation. So, the pharmacological method is preferred in these situations.

Mechanical methods are advised in patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours such as after minor trauma. The simplest method is for the patient to ambulate. The activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Additionally, compression stockings are advised. It can reduce the risk of DVT by exerting graduated pressure on the leg, with the pressure being greatest at the ankle.

Advantages of LMWH over unfractionated heparin: 

  • LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability.
  • The consistent bioavail­ability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of aPTT or anti-factor Xa activity.
  • Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight.
  • There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin.

LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1:1 to 4:1.

questions.text: The downward displacement of the spleen is prevented by which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
The phrenocolic ligament prevents the downward displacement of the spleen.

The phrenicocolic ligament is not attached to the spleen. questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) is not true?

choices.text: No specific focus of infection is seen
It is more common when splenectomy is done for malignancy and hematological disorder than for trauma
Initial presentation involves fever and chills
Most cases occur within 1 year of splenectomy

questions.solution:
Most cases of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) occur within the first 2–3 years after splenectomy.

OPSI is the most common fatal complication of splenectomy mainly caused by organisms such as S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, and H. influenzae with S. pneumoniae.

Risk factors include young age, thalassemia major, sickle cell anemia, lymphoma, idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, and an immunosuppressed state.

OPSI is characterized by fever, rigors, chills, and other nonspecific symptoms like sore throat, malaise, myalgias, diarrhea, and vomiting which can progress to fulminant infection and multiorgan system failure with the development of hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagulation, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presentation.

Asplenic or hyposplenic patients are recommended to take the following vaccines prophylactically-

  • 13- valent pneumococcal conjugate (PCV 13) vaccine followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) at least 8 weeks later
  • H. influenzae type b conjugate vaccine
  • Quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate ACWY vaccine series
  • Monovalent meningococcal serogroup B vaccine series 

In addition, they should receive seasonal influenza vaccination, measles, mumps, rubella, varicella, tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.

The vaccines should be ideally given 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy and at least 14 days prior to surgery or 14 days after splenectomy incase of emergency procedure.

Daily antibiotic prophylaxis is preferred for children up to 16 years of age or a minimum 3-5 years post-splenectomy. Oral antibiotic of choice is amoxicillin or oral penicillin (macrolide in case of hypersensitivity). 

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about insulinoma is false?

choices.text: Majority of insulinomas are benign and solitary
Insulinomas occur more commonly in females
Insulinomas occur more commonly in the tail, than in the head and body of pancreas
Mean age at diagnosis is 45 years

questions.solution:
Insulinomas are dis­tributed equally throughout the pancreas, despite the predominance of beta-cells in the body and tail.

The majority (90%) of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and only 10% are malignant and multifocal. Malignant insulinomas are usually found in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome. Insulinomas are typically small, with an average size of 1.0 to 1.5 cm.

Insulinomas occur more commonly in females, between 40–60 years of age with the mean age of diagnosis at 45 years.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is related to the triangle shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Passaro’s triangle, which is related to gastrinomas. Around 90% of gastrinomas are found within this triangle. 

The three points forming this triangle are the junction of the cystic duct and the common bile duct, the junction of the second and third portion of the duodenum, and the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas.

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 (MEN-1) syndromes in the familial pattern.

Other options:

Option (A): Insulinomas are insulin-secreting tumors of the pancreas that cause hypoglycemia. They are found either in the pancreas or attached directly to it. They are not found specifically within this kind of anatomical triangle. 

Option (B): Glucagonoma should be suspected when a patient has diabetes associated with dermatitis. Necrolytic migratory erythema is one of the classical skin manifestations seen in these patients. These tumors are found in the body and tail of the pancreas.

Option (D): Vasoactive intestinal peptide tumor (VIPoma) is also called watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome. It is a tumor that is most commonly found in the distal pancreas.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.
